Award.AbstractNarration:
Precise experimental tests of fundamental particle properties are now a well-established way to search for new laws of nature beyond our current physical knowledge. This research program centers around two experiments to make precise measurements of physical properties of the neutron. The first experiment, called UCNA, is being carried out at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, using extremely slow neutrons (ultra-cold neutrons, or UCN), which have such low energy that they can be stored in magnetic "bottles". This allows the experiment to make a precise measurement of the direction of the electron emitted when a neutron decays into a proton, an electron and a particle called an anti-neutrino. This provides needed information about the theory of radioactivity (also called the weak nuclear force). In addition, the PI and his group are developing equipment for a future experiment to search for a possible electric dipole moment (EDM) of the neutron. The existence of this EDM would be a signal of new physics beyond our current knowledge and could help to explain why the universe is dominated by matter, whereas the Standard Model of particle physics predicts there should be nearly equal amounts of matter and antimatter. Participation by postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and undergraduates is an essential part of the research program, affording young researchers exceptional opportunities to advance their training and education in this frontier area of nuclear physics.

This project is primarily focused on experimental research addressing fundamental properties of the free neutron. In particular the group will continue analyzing data from the UCNA experiment while also constructing hardware for a new, highly sensitive experiment to search for the neutron's EDM. The UCNA experiment will provide a high precision measurement of the beta-asymmetry in neutron decay using Ultra-Cold Neutrons for the first time. This quantity allows a sensitive test of the unitarity of the weak quark-mixing matrix and has the potential to provide evidence for new physics beyond the Standard Model of particle interactions. With recent improvements to the apparatus the group is poised to improve the precision on the asymmetry down to ~ 0.3% with additional data-taking and analysis during the period of this grant. The goal of the new EDM experiment, called nEDM, is being done at the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Laboratory and will improve the upper limit by a factor of 100 compared to previous measurements; observation of an EDM signals violation of time-reversal and charge-parity (CP) symmetry, and could provide important information related to the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry of the universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on precision measurements of the properties of both the weak and strong forces of nature. These are two of the four know forces of nature which include gravity, electricity and magnetism, the weak and the strong force. Precision measurements of such forces have two goals; one is to provide a better understanding of these forces in order to be able to calculate their effects in both terrestrial and astrophysical environments and another goal is to push our understanding of these forces to the limits of measurement to search for deviations or breakdowns in the assumed physical laws associated with these forces. Such failures of the physical laws could signal the emergence of new physical principles or forces. This work provides important information for nuclear science and is also of great interest to the related fields of astrophysics and elementary particle physics.

Our primary focus is on studying the free neutron. Neutrons make up more than half of all terrestrial matter, but when they are free (i.e. removed from atomic nuclei) they decay with a half-life of about ten minutes. As a result of our research we have published new high precision results on the decay distribution of the free neutron. Recently we have also used these data to search for a possible new decay mode of the neutron to a possible dark matter particle. Dark matter is believed to be very weakly-interacting matter that clumps around galaxies. In order to carry out this research we helped develop one of the world’s most intense sources of ultra-cold neutrons. These are free neutrons that move so slowly they can be trapped inside vacuum containers for extended periods, allowing for careful, precision measurements. We are also playing a leading role in developing a new high sensitivity search for a violation of time symmetry in the free neutron. Time symmetry implies that physical laws are identical whether the arrow of time is moving forwards or backwards. Our experiment hopes to improve this sensitivity by a factor of 100 compared to existing experiments to discover this property which could help explain why there is so little antimatter in our universe. Our present understanding of the Big Bang cannot account for this imbalance between the amounts of matter and antimatter in the observable universe. We are presently building and testing the magnetic system at Caltech for this experiment.

This research has also had a major impact in the education of nuclear scientists (which are a critical component of the US scientific workforce). In particular, this project has engaged seven undergraduate students in basic research while training three graduate students who are working towards their PhD, as well as the mentoring of two postdoctoral researchers.
